description: This two-semester course is to help students develop their ability to properly express themselves in written English. In the first semester, students are expected to acquire the fundamentals of English paragraph-writing, including structure (topic sentence, controlling idea, support and conclusion), outline, organization and coherence. In the second semester, students will extend their one-paragraph writing skills to three-paragraph short-essay writing. In addition, this course aims to equip students with analytic writing competence in response to different scenarios. In particular, course assignments will cover intensive writing practices in different modes, including description, narration, process, cause-effect, comparison-contrast, definition, and classification.
goals: This class is to help students improve their skills in writing English paragraphs/essays.

Course Description

**Guided Writing**

1.  **Goal**: 

This course is designed to foster effective English written communication in an academic setting. By directing students’ attention to the rhetorical features of English language writing, students will be aware of the English academic writing conventions that are commonly practiced in academic communication and thus use the conventions in their English writing. To achieve this goal, academic texts will be analyzed so as to promote the awareness of global and local rhetorical strategies used by the authors. For writing practice, the primary focus will be on paragraph-level writing. Five major rhetorical, thinking patterns will be introduced and practiced, including cause, effect, comparison, contrast, and argument. Cohesive devices that cue for these patterns will also be attended to.

**II. Content**:

Textual strategies: identifying/analyzing audience, promoting audience awareness, setting writing goals/purposes, working on topic sentences, supporting topic sentences, establishing global and local coherence by making cohesive ties explicit, organizing ideas in enumeration, and maintaining paragraph unity by elucidating topic relevance.

General writing strategies: Generating ideas through brainstorming, surveying, and discussion in the classroom; outlining, drafting, getting feedback from peers, revising, and editing.

**III. Class Policies:**

1\. Students are expected to attend each class—attendance will be taken. Multiple absences may result in an automatic failing grade.

2\. Students who miss class are responsible for course content. Any student who misses a class has the responsibility for obtaining copies of notes, handouts, assignments, etc.

3\. All typed assignments completed outside of class must be **1.5-spaced with 12 font-size**.

4\. All assignments must be proofed by the online tool, **Grammarly**. Excessive errors in spelling, word usage, and grammar will be penalized with a deduction of 20 points. 

5\. Written assignments must be turned in on time; penalties will be enforced for late-ins.

6\. All cell phones MUST be turned off during class time. 

7\. Academic honesty is expected at all times. Plagiarism will result in a serious grade penalty and may lead to **an automatic failing grade**.

**IV. Assignments**:

A. **Assignments on five topics**: Each topic will be done in a tri-weekly cycle: 1) **first-draft** (Please bring **3 hard copies** to class for peer response on the content and organization, 2) **second-draft**, to be turned in **on MOODLE** for teacher-response one day (Thursday noon) before class time, and 3) **final-draft** posted **on MOODLE** within 6 days after teacher response given.

B. **A Learning Journal** will be written after each assignment is completed, recording what you learned from this round of writing (in at least 250 words).

C. **A Learning Portfolio**: include 5 topics of (**1st draft with feedbacks** & final drafts + journal), to be turned in by the end of the semester

**V. Schedule：** \*\*\*The due time for 2nd and final drafts to be turned in on MOODLE will be **Thursday noon.**
